Award.AwardTitle: LiT - Sublethal impacts of non-native species invasion
Award.AbstractNarration: Global environmental change, including habitat loss and the introduction of non-native species, poses a growing threat to native animals. The lethal outcomes of such threats have received much attention, but animals that survive can also suffer important consequences; growing more slowly, having suppressed immune systems, and producing fewer offspring. These consequences are poorly understood, but they can have important implications for the ability of native populations to persist in the face of these threats. This project will adopt a range of ecological and biomedical measures of animal health in the field and laboratory, from cellular immune function to measures of the reproductive capacity of individuals, to examine the impact globally-invasive fire ants are having on native lizards. It will also test how long-term exposure to this invasive pest can influence the threat-tolerance of these invaded populations; whether native populations become more or less resilient to the consequences of this threat. The results of this research will help us to understand how native populations are able to persist in the face of increasing environmental change, and provide important information needed to guide the conservation of global biodiversity. This project will also provide education and training of students and the general community. Graduate and minority undergraduate students, as well as K-12 students from minority-serving institutions, will be involved in the laboratory and field components of this work, and the local community will be engaged through displays and presentations of the results of this research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Understanding interactions between organisms and their environment is a fundamental goal of ecology. Changes in the environment are becoming increasingly frequent and intense due to human activity, and such changes can impose significant pressure on native populations. We need to understand how novel threats impact organisms and how native species are able to persist in the face of threats imposed by global environmental change, if we are to predict and manage this growing conservation concern. Lethal impacts of these perturbations have been well documented. Sublethal consequences may be just as important, but are less well understood.

 This research exploits an exciting new system of aggressive invasive fire ants and native lizards to examine the ecological consequences of non-native species invasion. Impacts are measured on traits that range from cellular (hormones and immune function) to whole-animal performance (growth rates and reproduction), and provide critical insights into the long-term impact of globally important invasive species and other anthropogenic perturbations.

 Our work reveals that invasive species can cause elevated physiological stress levels in the native populations they invade. This stress can have important impacts on individual behavior and stress physiology. These effects can occur through exposure of offspring to stress during development, through exposure of individuals to stress within their lifetime, and through population-level exposure to stress across generations (suggesting adaptation). We found that the presence of this invasive stressor reverses the natural latitudinal trend in corticosterone (CORT, a stress-relevant hormone) levels, and behavioral and morphological response to ant predators; suggesting potentially important costs of adaptation that should be examined. We found that the nature of the stressor matters (application of CORT, handling, exposure to a predator), necessitating consideration of the ecological relevance of stressors used in future research, and of documenting and reporting the frequency, intensity and duration of natural stressors during field studies. 

Together, these results highlight the importance of understanding the sublethal consequences of environmental stress for managing native populations.

Several personnel were trained under this award; the work involved 2 postdoctoral fellows, 6 graduate students, 14 undergraduate students, 3 minority high-school students, and one K-12 teacher.

The public’s fascination with fire ants allowed us to use this research as a tool to engage citizens in scientific research that is relevant to their daily lives. We directly involved inner-city high-school students in this research, and they are co-authors on resulting publications. We teamed with environmental education centers to organize summer camp activities for school aged children in Alabama. This work has attracted general audiences for Science Café events organized by a graduate student on this project, and at outreach days held at Penn State University and national events.

 The results of this work have been reported in 8 scientific publications, 22 talks at universities and scientific meetings, and in the media through outlets including Science Magazine. We post weekly blog articles about this and related research on our Lab Blog: http://thelizardlog.wordpress.com/, which attracts hundreds of viewers each month.
